Doom was a series that blew me away when I was younger. I was born right before the advent of 3D gaming, so I grew up with the progression from 16-bit to 32-bit and then full on polygonal games. It felt like technology was moving so fast and that I was at the cusp of creativity.  Even though Super Mario 64 had changed how I viewed gaming, Doom came into my life and changed what I thought of my PC. I now wanted to master the keyboard and mouse so that I could become a Doom god. I eventually got my own PC and Doom became my best friend.  What I found was, I had a stronger fondness for Doom II. I couldn't explain it then, but I felt like the game was more intense. It seemed to move faster, had bigger levels and a greater variety of enemies. Even if it bared resemblance to the original Doom, it felt like a totally different game.  I can now explain why I felt such a way. ID Software were always looking to outdo themselves. All of the creators had become masters of their own game, so they looked on how to up the challenge. Throwing simply more enemies would be cheap, but it also could work with some slight modifications to the gunplay.  This brought about the Super Shotgun (or Double Barrell), which has such a significant impact on combat scenarios and level design. Since you basically have a gun that is close range with the damage of a rocket launcher (and no splash damage), you can destroy lesser foes in a single shot.  It turns some of the drawn out encounters from the first game into lightning fast executions. You can clear out rooms of weaklings in mere seconds, where the original Doom required you to carefully plan out whom to attack first. That does still factor into Doom II, what with the enemies retaining their simplistic designs and the new enemies being super deadly; the change is now that there are dramatically more enemies.  The levels are much larger than anything from the first game, so you will encounter hundreds of foes in single levels. Your arsenal will grow over the course of the game and you'll eventually find yourself with a large amount of ammunition. If nothing was done to even the odds, you'd be overpowered within 5 levels.  While not every map is a masterpiece, the majority of this game has more in-depth designs. Vertical spacing is delved into; differing level heights play a bigger role; there are even some gimmick levels that throw large bosses at you with a small puzzle to kill them. It's definitely not just bigger = better.  The game also does away with Episode selection and has you play all 30 levels back to back. If you get good at the game, you end up never losing your inventory. Most of the levels have ammo backpacks, so even if you do die, you're never left underpowered. You may run out of ammo, though.  The newer enemies help flesh out the roster a bit. The original game nearly blows it's entire line-up in the first Episode, saving the really big bosses for the later levels. Doom II introduces one weaker version of a previous enemy (the Hell Knight) and some real pain in the ♥♥♥, priority targets.  The Mancubus is basically a walking tank with double rocket launchers; the Pain Elemental acts as a mobile spawning point; the Revenant is hyper fast and strong (though with low health); finally, the Chaingun Guy has impeccable accuracy and speed with his chaingun. It introduces a more steady difficulty curve that doesn't need to reset at the start of every 8 or so levels (like how the original Doom handled it).  The Steam version of Doom II is also limited to being a DOSBox emulation (much like it's predecessor), so that does suck. With the aid of a source port, you can also get some co-op going. You can even clean up the visuals a bit and add some more modernized controls.  Overall, Doom II may not be as brilliantly made as the first game. I still enjoy the combat and larger levels more, but there is a sense that ID Software got a bit too ambitious. Regardless of that, there is no reason to pass up on playing this.  9/10

Doom was the successor of the Wolfenstein series, and the second in its series was released in 1994 and will run on any computer system on the planet - unless you're exceptionally unfortunate.  Doom 2 is a fun, action packed monster slaying journey. The game has spawned an entire series and several variations have been officially made along with a still-active modding community similar to the still-active modding community of the original Wolfenstein games from id software.  In a twist of fate for those of us who understand it well, the story is that Earth has been completely invaded by the monsters of Hell and any survivors were sent into outer space to preserve the human race. Working his way through the hordes of Hell, Doomguy comes to fight the Spider Mastermind, Cyberdemon and finally the Icon of Sin. The icon of sin is the interesting twist, where the icon of sin represents John Romero - the games artist who was disinterested in the games art style and subsequently left id software. There's an easter egg for if you use no clipping and go to the right place, you can see the head of John Romero on a spear and even has animations for when being shot.  There are epic fights with countless monsters, and the fun and challenge is nostalgic, undeniable and instantly classic. It should be noted that many of the difficulties of the array of mods and releases feature difficulties intended to be impossible to complete - where some people have actually achieved victory. I find these victories quite impressive.  It's cheap, fun, nostalgic, action-packed and runs well on any system, have you any reason not to play Doom at least once in your life?

Well, the game itself sucks. Obviously, it was mind-blowingly cool for when it came out, but for todays standards... You have a little tiny bit of installer work to do, but once you do, it's totally worth the price.There's mods that simply improve the games mechanics and graphics, to mods that completely overhaul and change the game. They stretch far and wide, from anime-style demon slaying action, magic spells, punching people in the face, MAP PACKS, and of course straight up rip and tear brutality. The community has kept this game alive. On some particular mods, like Zandronum, the game even has an active multiplayer community. Wow.  You need to buy this game for the mods, by the way. No pirating for you!  Yeah, as long as your willing to do a little digital labour, this game is totally worth it. This goes for all of the other Doom games too, most if not, all mods work for all of them.

Good enemy designs have always made video games interesting. They not only appeal to the eye and offer challenging opponents. Doom II does both very pleasingly. The level designs are not the most realistic by comparison to the ones of the games today, but they offer effective battlegrounds. The weapons remain unchanged, but the double barrel shotgun adds an impressive new tool. Getting to spray pellets over a large area gives players the chance to kill several monsters at once in a rather spectacular fashion, well rendered by the many spirits.  Doom II was among the first titles to introduce interactive three dimmensional objects and settings. They were still developing, but at the stage ID Software was, Doom II brought the seeds that would later blossom into the modern FPS shooters. It certainly presented some interesting concepts of physics, such as the BFG and the artificial goat's head that spawned living creatures from cubes.

Things like sprites and buildings gradually more pixelated. This may have to do with Dosbox as the source port, but you can fix this by using Zandronum or GZDoom to make the game look more 3D, including display options to change the resolution. DOOM's still playable on Steam and fun as hell, but useing GZDoom or Zandronum will partially enhance sprite quality and and looks better overall.
